componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just squeeze the a. Hey, Rami, just on the new product announcements, you've had a slew of them in the last 3 to 6 months, which 1, 2 or 3 do you think would start to add to revenues as we move towards through the rest of 2015 and into 2016?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Amitabh. First, I feel really good about the products and the announcement that we just unveiled to the industry. These are obviously technologies that we have been working on very diligently over the last several years, and Q1 was honestly v
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Amitabh. First, I feel really good about the products and the announcement that we just unveiled to the industry. These are obviously technologies that we have been working on very diligently over the last several years, and Q1 was honestly very exciting for us because we finally had an opportunity to announce to everybody what is that we've been up to. And as you know, they really touch all of our different business areas in Switching, Routing and Security. I have to sort of just remind everybody that yes, these products all go through their normal certification cycles. We have to first get them out to market. So right now, we're all working around-the-clock to make sure that we get them in our customer's hands and ready for deployment, crossing all the T's and dotting the I's, if you will, on the testing that needs to happen right now. I expect the first products that hit market will be the Switching product. And there, I think the ramp will be sooner just based on the availability of that product to the market, followed by the enhancements that we made to the PTX product line that happens in the Q3 time frame.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Simona Jankowski from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Simona Jankowski from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions as a follow-up to the prior question on the new product. So Rami, based on your guidance for both Q2 and the second half, it sounds like you're not really expecting a pause or kind of an Osborne effect because of these new produ
componenttext: Just a couple of questions as a follow-up to the prior question on the new product. So Rami, based on your guidance for both Q2 and the second half, it sounds like you're not really expecting a pause or kind of an Osborne effect because of these new products as customers wait for the better products to come out later in the year. Can you just comment on why that is? And then follow-up specifically on the portfolio. We haven't seen you announce anything in the area of 25 or 50 gig in the data center or 2.5 gig in campus. Can just comment on whether those are segments that you plan to address?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Simona. Thanks for the question. First, on the overhang effect that you're talking about, we've gone through project transitions at Juniper now a number of times. So obviously are aware and always factor into our projections and our plan the po
componenttext:
Yes, sure, Simona. Thanks for the question. First, on the overhang effect that you're talking about, we've gone through project transitions at Juniper now a number of times. So obviously are aware and always factor into our projections and our plan the potential for any sort of an overhang effect. But that said, I'm just going to drill 1 level deeper. We've been talking to our customers about these innovations for quite a long time now. in fact with many of our customers, we've developed new products with direct input and guidance from them. So it's not going to the new news for them. Secondarily, in the -- let's see the routing demand with the PTX, here, our customers have actually really like the fact that we're to invest in this product line. And so they know they have the peace of mind, if you will, that they can continue to purchase it and have the ability to upgrade in the future when their capacity requires them. On the Switching sides. I'd say the overhang effect is slim to none because of the fact that this essential addresses the gap that exists in our portfolio as opposed to something that replaces a product line that's already in the market.
On the -- your follow-up question on 25 gig and some of these new interface , we haven't got out externally and talked about the specific products. All I'd say for now is that actually, this is an important topic for us in the company. We understand what our customer requirements are with respect to very different interface speed, and we're believe that into our roadmap.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then I just had a very quick follow-up for Robyn. Robyn, I heard your comments on FX having not had a translational impact, which makes sense. It was interesting how strong your EMEA business was. Did you not see any impact in terms of either deal sid
componenttext: And then I just had a very quick follow-up for Robyn. Robyn, I heard your comments on FX having not had a translational impact, which makes sense. It was interesting how strong your EMEA business was. Did you not see any impact in terms of either deal side is getting smaller or competitively or in terms of pricing just from how strong the dollar was?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So clearly, in the first quarter, we did have very good results in our EMEA business. It was actually up year-over-year. In terms of the pricing impact, it is a competitive market, and we continue to take into account the currency impact on our customers'
componenttext: So clearly, in the first quarter, we did have very good results in our EMEA business. It was actually up year-over-year. In terms of the pricing impact, it is a competitive market, and we continue to take into account the currency impact on our customers' budget, if you like, as opposed to just their own product pricing. And so these are factors that we've dealt with in the past and we will continue to do with the that. Obviously, going forward, we factored in what we believe will be the impact from currency into the guidance that I've given you for the second quarter and then also, more in terms of color for the second half of the year as well.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from Pierre Ferragu from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rami, first of all, you -- so we're looking at consolidation in the industry. of course, you mentioned the Nokia Alcatel-Lucent merger. And so I'd love to hear your thoughts a little bit, first of all, how do you see that affecting you guys like more cons
componenttext: Rami, first of all, you -- so we're looking at consolidation in the industry. of course, you mentioned the Nokia Alcatel-Lucent merger. And so I'd love to hear your thoughts a little bit, first of all, how do you see that affecting you guys like more consolidation in the industry. And this I would say beyond is a direct conductor and Nokia being 1 of your distributors. And then also I'd love to hear your thoughts about how you see industry evolving going forward. Do you think that would be more consolidation? Do you think you can play that? And I'm thinking about 2 things, could Juniper be stronger as opposed to a large entity? We always provide our clients? And also from a technology call perspective, how do you think about you guys potentially being stronger, closer to technologies like transport versus being independent and focused on IP repayment. and then I have a very short question for Robyn.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you, Pierre. So certainly, we see the industry dynamics that are panning out right now. Consolidation is one of those industry dynamics. And difficult to predict. But yes it could continue going forward. There are other dynamics that ar
componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you, Pierre. So certainly, we see the industry dynamics that are panning out right now. Consolidation is one of those industry dynamics. And difficult to predict. But yes it could continue going forward. There are other dynamics that are happening as well. There are transformational architectural shift that are happening right now across the industry of a movement towards cloud-based service delivery value delivery to the end-users whether that be residential or business end-users. And honestly, I believe that there is a need for a company that's going to be really laser-focused on developing the types of IP innovation that are necessary to get our customers to make this transition. That's the role that we play in the company. That the role we play at Juniper. So the net of it is there are still change our strategy. Our strategy remains one of delivering and competing based on the merit of our technology and on achieving scale through really effective partnerships. With respect to Nokia, Robyn addressed it in her opening remarks, we had deep, direct relationships with all of the customers that we work with whether they go through Nokia or not, and we have a variety of other partners to choose from as well in taking our innovation to market. As far as the second part of your question with respect to potential M&A for Juniper, I have said in the past, and I still do believe, that our strategy to innovate is going to be largely organic but with the potential to augment it with M&A activity. Right now, the focus is primarily on getting the products that we've announced out the door, but at some point it probably makes sense for us to think about M&A to complement that and we continue to do that as part of our ongoing strategic process.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: And Robyn, a very quick follow-up on the $690 million [ph] of business you've generated with Nokia last year, how should we think about how sticky it has been? componenttext: Thanks, Pierre, that is a good question. I mean, from our perspective, obviously, what the control is actually our relationships with our customers, our end-user customers. In terms of the profile of that $190 million for 2014, if was both product and services. If was actually Routing, Switching and Security in those numbers. Clearly, there is some of overlap in terms of routing with the Alcatel-Lucent portfolio as and when these transactions closes, I'm sure that will take some time. So we believe that there is an opportunity to continue to partner on those areas. But we don't know the lesson. And then obviously, the services contract continue over time with those end-user customers. And so, and the profile of the revenue products and services is roughly the same as the overall Juniper profile in terms of overall percentage.

A couple like a year or so out so we can kind of track the progress of the new products. And then I have a very quick just small follow-up.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Ehud, I'll address the second part of the question and then Rami can address the first part around customer consolidation.So in terms of the new product ramp to revenue, obviously, we're very focused on doing that. And the Rami through the number of
componenttext:
So Ehud, I'll address the second part of the question and then Rami can address the first part around customer consolidation.
So in terms of the new product ramp to revenue, obviously, we're very focused on doing that. And the Rami through the number of steps that we need to do in terms of getting the products out and then also having been satisfied to the networks and that type of thing. We have not without nor are we going to put out a number in terms of the quantity of revenue to expect. What we will do is give you progress. We incurred design wins and that type of thing here but in terms of an overall number, it's included in our goals for the second half of the year ended, and it will be modest this year in terms of any revenue impact.
CEOXEC02
Thanks, Robyn. On the question regarding cable, first, I will remind everybody that cable is one of our key strategic verticals that we are focusing on and measuring ourselves against in terms of performance of the business. We enjoy a really strong relationship both -- on both sides of the potential merger he talked about, Comcast and Time Warner. And we continue to do so. We're working very closely with them on a variety of different projects. I personally engage with executives on both sides. So honesty, whether it happens or not, is a very neutral thing for us. It doesn't change the importance of the vertical for us, it doesn't change our invest level that we put into the vertical to make sure that we remain aligned with the innovation that we are aligned into the market. And I would say that some of the new product that we have just talked about were developed with explicit and detailed feedback about the requirements for the cable industry. We know what they want, we know what kind of performance, the capability, the feature sets, that is required to build-out their network. And I feel confident that they're actually going to play us out very well for that vertical.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Tal Liani from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question is from Tal Liani from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first one is kind of way longer term. I understand that routing will have cyclical recovery. But if I try to think outside of the -- in terms of kind of recovery, in the last 4 years, Routing revenues were flat, 0% growth. What do you think is the out
componenttext: The first one is kind of way longer term. I understand that routing will have cyclical recovery. But if I try to think outside of the -- in terms of kind of recovery, in the last 4 years, Routing revenues were flat, 0% growth. What do you think is the outlook? What is -- even if you don't get to  the's specific number, what are the puts and takes growth over the next 4 or 5 years? Why should it accelerate now if it didn't grow the last 4 years, if you take the whole 2011 to 2015? The second question is about the outlook for cost cuts, if at all. So you're coming out of a big restructuring program, is that it? From a cost cut point of view. So going forward, will margin expansion be more a function of revenue growth? Or is there any room for additional cuts?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start, Tal, and then I'll pass it over to Robyn. The outlook that we have provided on our Routing business over the next 3 years was essentially 3% to 5% in revenue growth. And I believe that's achievable because a number of different things. First
componenttext: Let me start, Tal, and then I'll pass it over to Robyn. The outlook that we have provided on our Routing business over the next 3 years was essentially 3% to 5% in revenue growth. And I believe that's achievable because a number of different things. First, just based on the merits of our product portfolio. The dynamics in the Routing business are such that in order to grow, you need to take market share. And in order to take market share, you need to have better products. But we just introduced a router that has 3x the performance up anything else that's out there in the industry today at the time that traffic is growing substantially and our customers care about the economics of routing. We have a product that truly demonstrates to them what we're capable of doing and moving that amount of traffic cost-effectively. That's why, I think we have confidence in our ability to achieve these projections. And then as far as the restructuring cost that you're talking about, let me just start and I'll pass it over to Robyn. The most important thing that I think you need to understand if yes, last year was a year of restructuring for us. But going forward, I think -- we are going to make sure that investments we make in OpEx are going to be commensurate with the revenue growth. We're not going to get ahead of ourselves as we have done in the past, quite frankly, in terms of how we invest in the business. We have to see the growth that will give us the freedom, if you will, to invest in the business, not the other way around. Robyn, do you want to add anything?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Rami. I think, firstly, I'm very pleased with the cost performance in the quarter and also the year-over-year declines that we've actually achieved this quarter in terms of the cost. I think also just amplifying what Rami said, I mean, clearl
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Rami. I think, firstly, I'm very pleased with the cost performance in the quarter and also the year-over-year declines that we've actually achieved this quarter in terms of the cost. I think also just amplifying what Rami said, I mean, clearly, we put out in October the 25% is still our goal in terms of operating margin over the next 3-year period. And we're focused on doing that in a balanced way. We want to make sure that we continue to invest in the future of the company, which is obviously, the innovation that we're delivering to market. And we will, as Rami said, grow OpEx outside of this year slower than we grow revenue. And so that's how we will continue to expand operating margins just like we did in the first quarter on a year-over-year basis. So that is our strategy, and we're continuing to do that. So the other side of that, Tal, is that we're looking for cost improvements. A lot of those will be invisible because you have to actually take cost out to even keep it flat in any sort of environment. So we are very focused on the cost side, but in a balanced way.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from Mark Sue of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: It's good to see you're encouraging commentary. If I look at it from a historical perspective, you went through a period of product pruning. We now know that you will keep Routing, Security, and also Switching. As you balance your commentary with OpEx, are the submarkets or perhaps verticals where you might potentially retreat from and while you fortify your efforts into the other verticals of cloud, data center and service providers. just trying to get a sense of the can multiply and the ethics on the other end.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Last year was a busy and a tough year, quite frankly, because we had to make some difficult decisions about which particular product areas we're going to remain in and which ones we would divest and which ones we would unwind. That work is e
componenttext: Thanks, Mark. Last year was a busy and a tough year, quite frankly, because we had to make some difficult decisions about which particular product areas we're going to remain in and which ones we would divest and which ones we would unwind. That work is effectively behind us at this point in time. So I feel very good right now that we are not stretching ourselves too thin, that we are investing in areas and investing sufficiently in the markets that we are playing in order to differentiate the compete and to win. It's that simple. So at this point, the focus really is on the focus in our strategy that we have to grow top line, and we'll go from there. We're in execution mode.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I can add just as well, Mark, the work of on go-to-market side is also obviously yielding results. And if you at our strategy more deeply in terms of the vertical focus that we have, it's obviously, clearly focused on those customers that differentiate
componenttext: If I can add just as well, Mark, the work of on go-to-market side is also obviously yielding results. And if you at our strategy more deeply in terms of the vertical focus that we have, it's obviously, clearly focused on those customers that differentiate the network or run their business on the network across clouds, cable, carriers as well as strategic verticals in enterprise and government. And so we're very pleased with that. And partnering is a key element of making sure that we continue to get the growth rates from a revenue perspective and continue to drive operating margin expansion as well.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Robyn. And on that, as you look at market improvement confirming net income, how should we think about cash flow from operations considering the business when it comes along generates a lot of cash? Any thoughts on how we should thinking a
componenttext: That's helpful, Robyn. And on that, as you look at market improvement confirming net income, how should we think about cash flow from operations considering the business when it comes along generates a lot of cash? Any thoughts on how we should thinking about cash flow from operations this year?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. I think cash flow generation is a core strength of the business model that we have here at Juniper. I think that operating cash flow in particular does follow the operating margin, and the expansion of that will obviously, lead to more cash per
componenttext: Yes, Mark. I think cash flow generation is a core strength of the business model that we have here at Juniper. I think that operating cash flow in particular does follow the operating margin, and the expansion of that will obviously, lead to more cash per revenue dollar being generated. And so we're very pleased with our cash flow. And for the first quarter and even for the whole of last year that enabled us to continue to drive the investment that we made going forward, and also deliver a healthy return for shareholders in terms of the capital returns that we've been committed to.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from Rod Hall from JPMorgan.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to ask either 1 of you on the routing cycle, maybe a little bit more short-term question you guys seem to think that the routing circle is down 15% year-over-year and your numbers this quarter you're down 8%. It does kind feel like that w
componenttext: I guess I wanted to ask either 1 of you on the routing cycle, maybe a little bit more short-term question you guys seem to think that the routing circle is down 15% year-over-year and your numbers this quarter you're down 8%. It does kind feel like that was the right call for you anyway. Should we anticipate the routing cycle continuing to improve? And do you think that we're getting year-over-year growth in the second half in routing? So that's the first question I got. And then I'll just ask a follow-up after you guys answer that one.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start and then I'll see if Robyn wants to add anything. Just go back to the commentary we made, we do expect just based on the 2 factors that we've outlined, service providers spend in general and I'll talk telcos spend in general and specifically
componenttext: Let me start and then I'll see if Robyn wants to add anything. Just go back to the commentary we made, we do expect just based on the 2 factors that we've outlined, service providers spend in general and I'll talk telcos spend in general and specifically here in the United States, should improve in the second half of the year. And then also the further diversification of our business across the different key verticals that includes clouds, that includes cable. Now based on that, we do anticipate the second half to be better than the first half and also better than the second half of las t year. Robyn, anything else?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree with, obviously, everything Rami said there. I will also point out and I mentioned it in my CFO commentary that we actually had a good routing quarter in Q1 in enterprise as well. And that just speaks to not only the of the revenue, but some
componenttext: Yes, I agree with, obviously, everything Rami said there. I will also point out and I mentioned it in my CFO commentary that we actually had a good routing quarter in Q1 in enterprise as well. And that just speaks to not only the of the revenue, but some of the key strategic pivots that we made last year around the data center. So obviously, in enterprise as well as in cloud data centers and the service provider world, there is an element of routing that's in those solutions as well. And so we're pleased by that performance. We saw some good wins and some good revenue on the Enterprise side of routing as well as the XP side. But to confirm, we do expect service provider routing to improve the year as well.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. and then my follow-up I guess is just a strategic question for you, Rami. And that's just as you look at the Routing business, I mean, it looks like over time anyway, routing and will come closer together. We know there's going to be organizational
componenttext: Okay. and then my follow-up I guess is just a strategic question for you, Rami. And that's just as you look at the Routing business, I mean, it looks like over time anyway, routing and will come closer together. We know there's going to be organizational reason the carriers thought going to happen, particularly in some of the bigger carriers. But I'm just wondering what you think about the process in the standalone we're having companies? How badly do you think you guys need to develop an optical capability -- a deeper optical capability I should say and you think it ever makes sense to acquire assets to provide that kind of capability?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rod, you're absolutely right. There is a transformation that's happening right now in the industry where the packet world, if you will, and the optical world are moving closely together. You're also right about the of which that's happening. It's not
componenttext: Yes, Rod, you're absolutely right. There is a transformation that's happening right now in the industry where the packet world, if you will, and the optical world are moving closely together. You're also right about the of which that's happening. It's not happening very fast. There's all sorts of nontechnology barriers that are in the way that will prevent it from moving very fast. As far as our own strategy, we do have a small but very effective optical team in Houston Juniper that I do expect will grow over time that has the capability of taking off-the-shelf optical components that are available to anybody really and integrate them to our routing products. But I also do believe that where most of the innovation is going to be on the packet optical convergence topic, it's going to be in software. It's going to be around the ability to look across layers and to make optimal decisions how 3 move information from place A to place B, leveraging possible and packet technology as efficiently and effectively as possible. And we have now a product called the NorthStar Controller, which is essentially our WAN SDN controller that does exactly that. honestly, I think we have some of the best minds in the industry right now that have developed algorithms that have the ability to optimize these path layers in ways that's very meaningful to our customers. And we're engaging with a number of different customers on this product. It's still early days, early stages, but I'm encouraged by the progress that we're making.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from Jess Lubert from Wells Fargo.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question on the Security business. Specifically, I was hoping to understand if you see any developments or do you believe this business maybe nearing a bottom? Would you expect the Security business to also strengthened through the year and poten
componenttext: I have a question on the Security business. Specifically, I was hoping to understand if you see any developments or do you believe this business maybe nearing a bottom? Would you expect the Security business to also strengthened through the year and potentially return to growth during the second half? And perhaps you can walk to what's ailing well enter the keys to better anticipating what seems to be up early vibrant Grady market.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Jeff. So our goal for this year, as I've stated last year -- sorry, last quarter, is around stabilizing the Security business. If you look at our SRX business in Q1, it was more or less flat with Q4. The part of the business that's in decline
componenttext:
Yes, thanks, Jeff. So our goal for this year, as I've stated last year -- sorry, last quarter, is around stabilizing the Security business. If you look at our SRX business in Q1, it was more or less flat with Q4. The part of the business that's in decline and that'll continue to be in decline is going to be legacy 3 business. This -- we're still in work in progress mode if you will on Security. I did mention that we've pivoted our strategy. We're now on a security strategy that's very highly aligned with the rest of our product portfolio in offering domain-level solutions that have a strong security element our customers, and we are executing on a very high level service engineering strategy. So just last week in fact, we announced the industry's fastest firewall, that's 2 terabits per second, for cloud operators that are trying to protect massive cloud infrastructure and for mobile operators that are trying to protect their mobile users, their mobile infrastructure. that's very, very meaningful, and it's only possible because of the silicon innovation that we've already developed in-house for our other product lines. And it just demonstrates the power of the synergies, if you will, from a cost standpoint that exists in your organization.
So in summary, we're focusing on a narrow part of the market, it's the network security space, tightly aligned with the rest of our product and we believe that we can, in fact, innovate to differentiate and win there. It's just going to take a bit of time.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rami, in the security business over the last couple of years, of a lot of your success has been at high-end with large service providers. As service provider spending improves in the back half of the year, should we expect that to also benefit the Securit
componenttext: Rami, in the security business over the last couple of years, of a lot of your success has been at high-end with large service providers. As service provider spending improves in the back half of the year, should we expect that to also benefit the Security business? And how are you thinking about Security with respect enterprise? Is the recovery likely to be were carrier focus and are you also expecting some more improvement on enterprise?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as CapEx improves for service providers, I expect that to help all of our business. I don't know whether specifically for the second half it'll have an effect on security. We haven't broken that out in that way. The enhancements that we are making r
componenttext: Well, as CapEx improves for service providers, I expect that to help all of our business. I don't know whether specifically for the second half it'll have an effect on security. We haven't broken that out in that way. The enhancements that we are making right now to our Junos Space security products, I want to make clear, are certainly very compelling for the service provider space but it's also compelling for large-scale enterprises. So those are building large enterprise clouds will benefit from the performance and scale that we're adding. and of course, it doesn't stop there. We are also continually enhancing our virtual security products and assets, which is very meaningful to the enterprise space, because at the end of the day, breaches will always happen. you're always going to be able to overcome any security barrier you put in the perimeter once that happens is the key is to prevent the spread of malware inside of the enterprise and our security products are being used by enterprises to do exactly that. So yes, our strategy is very around with SP and enterprise. The scale and performance both certainly more on the SP and the cloud infrastructure space but also on the enterprise side. And finally, virtualization is something that will certainly help both SP and enterprise.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to -- Jeff, just to understand that I made a comment regarding the routing and data center and the enterprise, the same is true in the quarter for security. The high-end was up, again, nothing to write home about yet because it was flat overall.
componenttext: And just to -- Jeff, just to understand that I made a comment regarding the routing and data center and the enterprise, the same is true in the quarter for security. The high-end was up, again, nothing to write home about yet because it was flat overall. SRX flat overall, sequentially. However, the area that's been growing nicely with actually the data center space in the enterprise in the first quarter. So it's early days, but our overall aim for this year is to create stability in that business this year and then go from there.

componenttext: Look we haven't broken it out. we can consider doing that at 1 point. I would say that the fact that we are seeing strength in cloud and cable and government is not an accident. And I feel good that that's going continue. I mean, I'll tell you again that the products that we have just announced that we'll be shipped throughout this year were all developed with a deep understanding of specific requirements in these verticals that others that might not have that strategic relationship that they may have with these customers would have implemented. So I expect that, that part of the business will continue to do well. And certainly the telcos side will do well as the -- there's improvement in the CapEx environment there.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just want to add one more point, Vijay. I think that the diversification of the revenue, the core strength of us. This quarter, one of the stats I'll leave you with is that of the top 10 customers in the quarter, 5 were carriers, 3 were outside of
componenttext: Yes, I just want to add one more point, Vijay. I think that the diversification of the revenue, the core strength of us. This quarter, one of the stats I'll leave you with is that of the top 10 customers in the quarter, 5 were carriers, 3 were outside of North America, we had 4 customers in the top 10 that were either cloud or cable and 1 Enterprise customer. So to me, that is -- it's really good in terms of the diversification. And it's not something that happened overnight. That's been working progress by the team for quite some time. It speaks to the strength of the go-to-market side as well as the relevance of the products across multiple customer tied. So we're pleased with that progress.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Excellent. So here's the question for you, Robyn. Juniper obviously is engaged in many initiatives, programs, many different types of customers to work with, how would you look at OpEx as a percentage of revenue for the remainder of the quarter of the yea
componenttext: Excellent. So here's the question for you, Robyn. Juniper obviously is engaged in many initiatives, programs, many different types of customers to work with, how would you look at OpEx as a percentage of revenue for the remainder of the quarter of the year? Do see that trending up as we get into new projects and an in the service provider site the Web 2.0 cloud has in terms of how they want to work with you. How should we look at OpEx?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so OpEx, as we talked about before, for this year, for 2015, we've set a gold of $1.9 billion plus or minus $25 million. As we move forward, we said earlier that we're committed to the 25% operating margin over the next 3 years. As we grow revenue, O
componenttext: Yes, so OpEx, as we talked about before, for this year, for 2015, we've set a gold of $1.9 billion plus or minus $25 million. As we move forward, we said earlier that we're committed to the 25% operating margin over the next 3 years. As we grow revenue, OpEx as a percentage of revenue will start to come down. And so we've talked about that for quite some time. The structural actions that we took last year and the cost areas that we continue to work on are a testament to that. So we're committed to doing that in a balanced way so that we can continue to grow the business over the long term. And we'll take the next question.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: The next question is from a Sanjiv Wadhwani of Stifel.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rami, a question on the Switching side. Last year, in the first half, you did really well in Switching touching in $200 million in revenues in the June quarter, which historically it's been tough to get there. I'm curious you're tracking about 30 -- $20 m
componenttext: Rami, a question on the Switching side. Last year, in the first half, you did really well in Switching touching in $200 million in revenues in the June quarter, which historically it's been tough to get there. I'm curious you're tracking about 30 -- $20 million, $30 million below that number. What's change between last year and this year and what gives you back to the $200 million mark or north of that?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. thanks, Sanjiv. On the Switching side, let me sort of try to break out the business and probably shed some light on some of the observations that you made. There is a service provider and an enterprise component to our switching business. the s
componenttext:
Yes, sure. thanks, Sanjiv. On the Switching side, let me sort of try to break out the business and probably shed some light on some of the observations that you made. There is a service provider and an enterprise component to our switching business. the service provider side, especially as it pertains to Cloud, have actually performed quite well and that includes performance in the Q1 timeframe, the quarter that we just wrapped up. The enterprise side is a mixed story, which is what you're seeing right now or observing right now in the numbers. Cloud, as it pertains to enterprise. So private cloud deployments as well as enterprise IT data centers have actually done quite well. So that area of the business just because I think of the focus and some of the newer product introduction has helped us grow in that area of the business.
On the campus side, your have the understand that the sort of did of certain of Kansas pivot in the Switching business of our strategy all up. That includes taking some of the products that we have in house Vegas, take our SSL VPN business, our polls business, the wireless LAN business and we've there to a partnership approach. And I think that, that strategy needs to play out over a number of quarters before we get the some sort of stability and return to growth, in you will. Once that happens, I think that will create the environment, if you will, for all of growth in Switching. Last but not least, clearly, we have been competing even in the data center without a complete portfolio of products wish we are just about to plug, if you will, with the innovations and the effect and gave product line that we have just another and will start to introduce for our customers in the middle of the year. That gives me more confidence again that I think Switching can be a good growth engine for the company going forward.

But you've had a couple of switch cycles in the past and you've kind of fumbled on them, whether they be cute fabric or and even the high end of your modular portfolio, the 9200 and the 8200. It never really managed to catch any traction. It seems like in modular, you've always had very difficult challenges. So what changes in the next cycle?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, at the end of the day, these are just words and it's the numbers that are going to have to prove our thesis, if you will, about our competitiveness in the space. But all I'll tell you is that we have learned tremendously, tremendously, from
componenttext: Well, I mean, at the end of the day, these are just words and it's the numbers that are going to have to prove our thesis, if you will, about our competitiveness in the space. But all I'll tell you is that we have learned tremendously, tremendously, from the lessons of introducing the products in some markets are in the market today whether they be on that yet side or the cute fabric side and so forth. And we have taken all of those lessons and applied them over the last couple of years that we were developing this new products in the -- into the development of those product lines. And in the -- we have now been talking to many of our customers about this product line for quite some time. And so far, what we've heard from them and in fact, some of them have had early access to the products in terms of an ability to actually kick the tires on them. The feedback have been quite encouraging. Now we have a lot of work to do to finish up testing, ramp up production and get them -- get these products into the market. We're doing exactly that right now, but I feel really good about the prospects of this product line.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very good. Lastly for me, HP announced its acquisition of Aruba. That was your Wi-Fi partner since you've exited your Wi-Fi business. Any thoughts on how you plug that hole since you're trying to plug a lot of holes?
componenttext: Very good. Lastly for me, HP announced its acquisition of Aruba. That was your Wi-Fi partner since you've exited your Wi-Fi business. Any thoughts on how you plug that hole since you're trying to plug a lot of holes?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well look, fortunately, I don't consider this a hole, at least not right now. Things could evolve in certain ways. But at this point in time, I am very close to the Aruba executive team. I've talked to their CEO. That partnership continues. The found
componenttext: Yes. Well look, fortunately, I don't consider this a hole, at least not right now. Things could evolve in certain ways. But at this point in time, I am very close to the Aruba executive team. I've talked to their CEO. That partnership continues. The foundation of that partnership is one that is based on open interfaces between our technology and their technology. So having the ability for our customers to choose best-of-breed technology is fundamental. And anybody that loses sight of that will lose just because our customers will not accept anything else. And I think that's the thing that makes this solution, A, long-lasting; but more importantly or just as importantly, it gives our customers the ability to entertain either Juniper or the Aruba side with different side of the technologies.

componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Brian. Let me start. So we're pleased with our enterprise performance, at least from a sequential standpoint. There are a couple of dynamics here. First and foremost, from an industry vertical standpoint, the government is actually helping here. We're seeing good strength in some projects that we have with the government agencies, and this helps us in switching, it helps us in routing, it also helps us to some extent in security as well. Beyond that, the focus that we have on this transformation that's happening toward cloud-based service delivery is very important. So we're working right now with a large Fortune 500 company in building their cloud infrastructure around the globe. And that is a testament to the strength that we have in our MetaFabric architecture, in the switching product that we've introduced to market, it's also a beautiful example of how security ties in really effectively to complete the cloud solution that we offer to our customers. I expect that to continue.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
