headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from James Faucette of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from James Faucette of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a similar question. If we go back to last year, last fall as you were kind of outlining your growth targets, one of the key tenants that you focused on was the eventual need for carriers increase their spending, particularly on core a
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a similar question. If we go back to last year, last fall as you were kind of outlining your growth targets, one of the key tenants that you focused on was the eventual need for carriers increase their spending, particularly on core as core capacity was exhausted. At the same time, as we fast forward to this year, service providers spending at least among the U.S., it's still been relatively flat without seeing much improvement there. I wonder if you could give a little bit of color what maybe allowing that carriers in U.S. to do that. And secondly, as they do start to increase their spend, how much of an additional tailwind can this be. It seems like the good growth you've seen with the U.S. Tier 1s kicking in perhaps an accelerator. And then similarly, on security, you're delivering good year-over-year growth in that line in spite of the fact that you're characterizing a stable 2015 as a stabilization year. So if that's the case, we should expect to see further acceleration, security and 2016 as your turned the corner and start to enter into what you think your true growth. Thanks.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, James. So thanks for the question. There's a lot in there. I'll see if I could address it all. First, in terms of carrier spending. As I mentioned, things are largely playing out as we expected in the second half. And I expect in the next quarter, Q
componenttext: Okay, James. So thanks for the question. There's a lot in there. I'll see if I could address it all. First, in terms of carrier spending. As I mentioned, things are largely playing out as we expected in the second half. And I expect in the next quarter, Q4, also this current quarter, to also be a good quarter for us in terms of carrier spending. The dynamics between core and Edge -- actually, I've been consistently saying that it's become very difficult to break out those 2 domains. Much of the pressure that's happening in telecom networks today is in fact happening in the metro, happening in the Edge. And a lot of the products that traditionally been used or deployed in the quarter, now actually going to the Edge to deal with that traffic capacity. So I'm really more measuring our success in carrier routing from overall routing standpoint as opposed to specific to one domain or the other. That said, despite the fact that we are seeing some improvement in Telcos, we are not counting on that alone in driving our overall revenue growth. We're counting on continued diversity in our business. We saw that play out in the last couple of quarters with cloud kicking in to help some weakness in carrier spending. We're seeing it now this quarter with diversity across the Enterprise, governments and different geos. All of that is kicking in to support the overall growth. And it's really been demonstrates the power of that strategy to diversify our business from a technology standpoint, from a market vertical standpoint and from a geo standpoint. On security, again, this year is all about stability as Robyn mentioned, essentially we're flat year-to-date. We still had -- I feel very good of what the work that has been done that far on shoring up our competitiveness on service provider, high-end security space and in the cloud. And we still have some work to do on the Enterprise side. Just in Q3, we announced a series of enhancements to our security portfolio under the umbrella of a new architecture called Juniper Unite, that essentially brings to bear our securities switching and routing assets together to create far more agility, simplicity and ease of management that's so important to Enterprise customers in the campus and in the campus domain. And that's what we're working on right now. And I think that, that plays out and result in growth in 2015 time frame.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And let me just add to the first part of your question. On telco, we actually saw good growth in the quarter both sequentially and year-over-year on telco globally. Modestly in the U.S., globally was a nice quarter for growth. So we are actually anticipat
componenttext: And let me just add to the first part of your question. On telco, we actually saw good growth in the quarter both sequentially and year-over-year on telco globally. Modestly in the U.S., globally was a nice quarter for growth. So we are actually anticipating that diversification to continue and we are expecting that to continue to improve. Again, modestly.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

And if you can give out those numbers maybe can you help us with, are sufficiently diversified now, do you feel comfortable whereby  Juniper could see cycle revenue growth and be, and you could offset on a continuous the typical service provider that we see.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks . So I know that data we have provided have been very useful. And we could look to providing an updated view in the future. From just a qualitative standpoint, the strategy itself is definitely working out in terms of helping us offset what is in f
componenttext: Thanks . So I know that data we have provided have been very useful. And we could look to providing an updated view in the future. From just a qualitative standpoint, the strategy itself is definitely working out in terms of helping us offset what is in fact cyclical industry. Do we believe that we can completely offset large cycles that might happen in Telcos? No. I think that's a pretty tall order. I think we demonstrated with not just diversity from a market vertical standpoint but diversity across technology areas switching and security and diversity across geos. If you look at Q3, Enterprise kicked in and also EMEA and APAC kicked in that helped us and again, grading the overall growth. I think this strategy works. I think it has legs and I think that they will help us in the future.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe just one very quick slightly different question. Let me ask you about the question from consolidation comes from Juniper perspective it seems to me that you guys are hitting most of the targets for heading towards more of the target you have won
componenttext: And maybe just one very quick slightly different question. Let me ask you about the question from consolidation comes from Juniper perspective it seems to me that you guys are hitting most of the targets for heading towards more of the target you have won. The ones that I've always been uncertain about is what's your approach to M&A given that you are achieving your margin structure, generating good cash return, cash growing, is now the time for Juniper be more active on the M&A front and do you maybe you can accelerate growth or is that not how you see the business?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm actually open to M&A and it will be as I mentioned historically, very much complementary to our strategy, tuck-in type technology M&A that will be easier and work to accelerate this strategy that we're already executing on. Having said that, we a
componenttext: Yes, I'm actually open to M&A and it will be as I mentioned historically, very much complementary to our strategy, tuck-in type technology M&A that will be easier and work to accelerate this strategy that we're already executing on. Having said that, we are so focused right now on putting the finishing touches on what is a huge product pipeline that's all coming to bear into the market simultaneously around the same time frame. I honestly do not want to distract the team too much from that right now. So time is going to be important. But that said, I do believe that M&A can be a good part of our strategy with the right timing and certainly something that's complimentary to our overall strategy.

Are there platform changes your customers are asking you to make or is that still about combining discrete asset, switching routing, Contrail, just trying to get an understanding of long trial opportunity current product said and how you're plotting to see clean data centers being deployed.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Martin. I will say you're actually hitting on a topic that's very important to me and to my leadership team. Today, the growth that we've seen with Juniper products in the cloud have largely been as a result of company's enterpris
componenttext: Thanks for the question, Martin. I will say you're actually hitting on a topic that's very important to me and to my leadership team. Today, the growth that we've seen with Juniper products in the cloud have largely been as a result of company's enterprises, Telcos, Cloud Providers, that have the ability to choose best to breed and to combine them in ways that solve the business challenges that they face. That said, there is a new part of the market segment on the market the value out of the box to converge architecture that includes storage, networking and software automation on top of that. We have in fact have been working with a number of different partners. So we probably have half a dozen right now, regional partners that are working with Juniper, as well as storage providers and compute providers, to build those stack offerings. And they typically are very targeted to specific market might verticals, so some might be targeting towards healthcare, others towards retail. And it's still early days. These are relatively new product offerings, but I actually, I feel pretty confident of their ability to at least give us some access to that converged or hyper converged market.

componenttextpreview: Oh, I see what you're saying. I think there is a balance here. The practice of revealing product years in advance of ship, I'd say, yes, that's something that's well behind us. We certainly will announce within a certain reasonable timeframe like a couple
componenttext: Oh, I see what you're saying. I think there is a balance here. The practice of revealing product years in advance of ship, I'd say, yes, that's something that's well behind us. We certainly will announce within a certain reasonable timeframe like a couple of quarters type of timeframe. And I think there's value in doing that because what you do is you prime the market, you get it ready for adoption. But we are very careful in not revealing our cards, if you will, too early. That said, there is always a lot of deep dialogue and engagement under MDA with our customers, where we're not only revealing the product but what we're actually stakeholders and development of those products and making sure that those products satisfies their specific requirements.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Ittai Kidron of Oppenheimer.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions first, looking at your Enterprise business, this is the first quarter in 5. After 5 quarter you have a year-over-year declines in your Enterprise business that you actually have a positive year-over-year growth in the Enterpri
componenttext: I have a couple of questions first, looking at your Enterprise business, this is the first quarter in 5. After 5 quarter you have a year-over-year declines in your Enterprise business that you actually have a positive year-over-year growth in the Enterprise. So Rami, it would be great to get some color as to how much of this is sort of a little bit of a reverse after 5 bad quarter versus your confidence in the more sustainable result of that business. And I'd like to kind of apply that question as well to your security business, clearly, you had 2 very good quarters. I'm just wondering how much of a reflection of clients have been sitting on the sideline. And now that you've refreshed the product, kind of updating architectures versus there are true new wins, new customers additions here. If you could just give us color in security, how much of the progress here in your existing install base versus adding new customer. That will be great. And then for you, Robyn, just as we think about next year, can you help us think about how to think about March quarter seasonality and also the pro forma tax rate for 2016.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start. First on the Enterprise. I'm certainly pleased with the performance. Three reasons. Cloud, cloud and cloud are essentially why we're seeing the success that we're seeing in the Enterprise. There's been a lot of focus on targeting Enter
componenttext: Sure. Let me start. First on the Enterprise. I'm certainly pleased with the performance. Three reasons. Cloud, cloud and cloud are essentially why we're seeing the success that we're seeing in the Enterprise. There's been a lot of focus on targeting Enterprise and service providers that are building on cloud architectures and product portfolio, the go to market focus, the support infrastructure we have in play is all geared towards tapping into that segment. And it is a growing segment. So I mean at the end of the day, while switching, for example, is a huge total addressable market, the cloud elements of is the part that's in fact growing. And we want to tap into that and we have been able to tap into that. It has been also just a big focus for me personally as part of the strategic initiative that I laid out this year from a standpoint of partnerships, creating the partnerships and the commercial engine that we need to tap into the overall Enterprise opportunity, specifically as it relates to the clouds. In security, it really is a combination. In fact, there has been a few notable wins in the last couple of quarters that are net new. Having said that, I think there are also customers that have traditionally the SRX, especially the high-end SRX, and the branch SRX that we are tapping into that need to modernize their infrastructure and we're tapping into that as well.  Again, we're not calling mission accomplished yet in security. There is a lot more work to do. And there might be a couple of gyrations here and there as we got into overall long-term growth which happens next year

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think the other area in Enterprise we are focusing on the channel as well. Using a lot of the Enterprise wins that we have been developing ourselves also in terms of cloud areas that Rami mentioned, as well as in the security siouse to reinvigorate
componenttext: And I think the other area in Enterprise we are focusing on the channel as well. Using a lot of the Enterprise wins that we have been developing ourselves also in terms of cloud areas that Rami mentioned, as well as in the security siouse to reinvigorate the channel, and put our design wins in the type of wins that we've been so that we can enable the channel to replicate them.  You asked 2 questions, one was to the tax rate, what was the other question?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about seasonality. At this point, it's obviously early. We'll give you more color next quarter call. But we're not anticipating anything outside of the normal seasonality that we would see between Q4 and Q1. So typically, we see a reduction so
componenttext: Let me talk about seasonality. At this point, it's obviously early. We'll give you more color next quarter call. But we're not anticipating anything outside of the normal seasonality that we would see between Q4 and Q1. So typically, we see a reduction somewhere between 7% and 10%, that type of thing. So we're not expecting at this point anything different to that. We'll give you an update of that on the next call. In terms of the tax rate, there was a lot of excitement in the tax rate commentary in this quarter, which is not usual. So on the pro forma GAAP tax rate, we will expect a slightly reduced rate. Obviously, the R&D tax credit not being renewed has had a an increase in our tax rate overall for the year. If that gets renewed, that can have close to a 2% tax rate adjustment. So at this point, we would see a significantly different tax rate for next year. Expect for the addition of the R&D tax credit.

componenttext: One you and your team. Question is really on the sustainability of the order flow in the cloud and cable. last question in terms of that segment has been doing well for you, cloud and cable providers, you also mentioned SaaS, et cetera. Are these one-offs kind of a near-term order float, do you see sustainability from a use case point of view that this reflects kind of multiple quarters? And then a quick follow on to that would be the service provider routing side. You had the routing business mis-consensus expectations in Q3. It's flattish x Junos Pulse quarter-on-quarter so give us kind of year-over-year order commentary there in the routing heading into Q4 and into over the next quarters.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Vijay, and congrats. Let me start and I'll see if Robyn has anything to add. On cloud and cable, I think those verticals have had lumpiness historically. And I'm not, let's say concerned about the relative weakness that we had sequentially in clou
componenttext: Thanks, Vijay, and congrats. Let me start and I'll see if Robyn has anything to add. On cloud and cable, I think those verticals have had lumpiness historically. And I'm not, let's say concerned about the relative weakness that we had sequentially in cloud in Q3. If you look at the year-over-year, it's actually quite healthy growth, a very healthy growth in fact. When I look at the fundamentals, cloud, the need to build efficient wider networks to connect the data centers together, to connect the data centers to the consumers and cloud services to peering points, it's all actually there. And I don't anticipate that changing. So the long-term trajectory and for this vertical to cost vertical, I believe is actually healthy. And the products that we're building with the specific capabilities for this vertical, the capabilities in terms of visibility and manageability, the controllability are well understood by Juniper. And we're developing our products with the intent of capturing the cloud opportunity in the future. Cable, as well can be lumpy, had been that historically. I think there's been consolidation that had been happening in the cable industry that will result in some short-term uncertainty, if you will. But the long-term prospects for us in cable I think are quite good. SP routing is all up. I think as I mentioned I feel actually quite good about where we are with respect to routing. Bookings were strong. I think it's the sequential softness in Q3, in North America, specifically had to do with timing of project, a difficult compare relative to Q2, with the revenue recognition event that we had in Q2 that we talked to you about. Visibility is good. And the roadmap is excellent.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Juniper Networks Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Kathleen Nemeth, Vice President, Investor Relations. Thank you, Ms. Nemeth. You may now begin.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and thanks for joining us to discuss Juniper Networks Third Quarter Financial Results and the Outlook for Fourth Quarter of 2015, which we announced earlier this afternoon. With me today are Rami Rahim, Chief Executive Officer; and Ro
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and thanks for joining us to discuss Juniper Networks Third Quarter Financial Results and the Outlook for Fourth Quarter of 2015, which we announced earlier this afternoon. With me today are Rami Rahim, Chief Executive Officer; and Robyn Denholm, Chief Financial and Operations Officer.
Today's call contains forward-looking statements, including statements concerning Juniper's business outlook, economic and market outlook, strategy, future financial operating results, capital return program and overall future prospects. Actual results might differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements. Additional information that could cause actual results to materially differ from those in these forward-looking statements are listed in our most recent 10Q, the press release furnished with our 8-K filed today and in other documents that we file with the SEC from time to time. All statements made during this call are made only as of today. Juniper undertakes no obligation to update the information in this conference call in the event facts or circumstances change after the date of the call. All statements made during this call are made only as of today. Juniper undertakes no obligation to update the information in this conference call in the event facts or circumstances change after the date of the call. 
Our discussion of the financial results today will include non-GAAP financial results. Full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information can be found on the Investor Relations section of our website. For important commentary on why our management team considered non-GAAP information a useful view of the company's financial results, please consult the press release furnished with our 8-K filed with the SEC today.
Now I'll hand the call over to Rami.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kathleen. Good afternoon, and welcome to our third quarter financial results call. Juniper delivered another quarter of strong financial performance with robust demand metrics and solid year-over-year earnings expansion. Our customer diversificati
componenttext:
Thanks, Kathleen. Good afternoon, and welcome to our third quarter financial results call. Juniper delivered another quarter of strong financial performance with robust demand metrics and solid year-over-year earnings expansion. Our customer diversification strategy continues to yield positive results, with revenue growth both sequentially and year-over-year across routing, switching and security. Notably, this quarter, we saw strong performance within our telecom and targeted Enterprise verticals. Security was also a highlight, with double-digit growth driven by our high-end SRX products. Overall, I'm pleased with the strong pipeline and execution across key areas of the business.
The industry is in rapid transition moving towards cloud delivered value. This paradigm shift to the cloud is changing the way we access technology and how IT services are being delivered. In this era of massive transformation, the network is at the heart of the action. Our goal as a pure-play and high-performance networking is to make sure we invest and innovate to capture this transformation as it is happening, and our customers are looking to us to support them in their evolution.
We continue to lead the industry with technology innovations. In the quarter, we announced the new reference architecture called Juniper Networks Unite for the cloud-enabled enterprise. It demonstrates our commitment to the enterprise campus and branch segment and our ongoing focus on IP network innovation. The new reference architecture includes our new Junos Fusion Enterprise fabric, which enables customers to simplify management of large enterprise campus network. We also announced new security innovations that will enable sophisticated threat intelligence, prevention and dynamic policy enforcement. 
We are forging new alliances and partnerships that will help us drive top line growth and market expansion. In the quarter, we extended our partnership with NEC to help provide IP transport routers to Telenor Group. We are also expanding our technology-aligned ecosystems, adding Aerohive Networks, who, along with Ruckus and Aruba, will help us deliver a simple, secured and cloud-managed wired and wireless solution for distributed enterprises. 
Because of our clear focus on execution, we're seeing some great customer and product traction. Among our top customers in the quarter are globally recognized high-tech companies, and 4 of our top 10 are cloud or cable providers. As our customers look to the future, they recognize Juniper's unique value proposition to deliver the ultimate in performance, agility and automation, and we empowering such companies, as British Airways and Telefonica Spain, to deliver world-class cloud services without compromise. In addition, we are pleased with several new design wins at multiple leading-edge technology companies.
I'll summarize some highlights this quarter across our technology. First, I want to underscore how strategic our Contrail solution is in defining the IT and business evolution to the cloud. Customers are moving towards open-source products, software-driven automation and containers in micro services. We've secured each headwind in 3 major segments: Software-as-a-Service, public cloud and telco cloud NFE. Of note, AT&T was a landmark deal for us this quarter.
In routing, we grew 13% year-over-year. Most verticals continued to grow with solid quarter-over-quarter growth in telecom and national government. We had another record revenue quarter for both the PTX and MX series. And in Q3, adoption of some of our newest products, the PTX5000, PTX1000 and ACX500, accelerated.
In switching, we had another record revenue quarter for the QFX series. The QFX10000 continue to see good traction, along with the QFX5100, with service providers, cloud and enterprise customers. We also saw strength in the EX family of switches with enterprise, government and service provider customer.
In security, we saw our second consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth, excluding Junos Pulse. Our security business is showing early strength in the high-end SRX with cloud and service provider customers, and branch SRX is doing well in government, managed service provider and enterprise account. We believe the combination of new threat detection capabilities and new security partnerships is a catalyst spurring our return to growth. The course we set for ourselves is now playing out largely as we anticipated. By remaining resolute in our focus as a pure-play and high-performance networking, we are creating tremendous value for our customers and our shareholders. 
Overall, while we acknowledge that recent industry consolidation activity could create some volatility, we believe overall spending trends remain healthy. Industry dynamics continue to unfold as we expected, and our Q4 guidance incorporates our view of the macro economic landscape. The world needs a company like Juniper Networks. We have a clear and deliberate strategy. And as a challenger in this industry, I continue to see tremendous opportunity for us to challenge the status quo and deliver on our vision of being the worldwide leader in network innovation. 
I want to thank each of our employees for being critical part of this incredible journey. And thanks to our customers, partners and shareholders who believe in our vision to empower everyone in this increasingly connected world. I remain focused on disciplined execution of our business and prudent investments for growth to realize Juniper's full potential. 
Now I'll turn it over to Robyn to review a few highlights of the quarter.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rami, and good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter 2015 results reflected good year-over-year and sequential revenue and earnings growth. We also demonstrated the strength of the diversity of our revenue across multiple verticals, technologi
componenttext:
Thank you, Rami, and good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter 2015 results reflected good year-over-year and sequential revenue and earnings growth. We also demonstrated the strength of the diversity of our revenue across multiple verticals, technologies and geographies. Specifically, we saw year-over-year and sequential revenue growth in both EMEA and APAC as well as solid growth in the Enterprise across all geographies. We are pleased with the ongoing year-over-year growth and healthy underlying demand from cloud providers. However, as we have noted, this vertical can be lumpy due to the timing of deployments.
As a reminder, our second quarter 2015 results for routing in the Americas were positively impacted by the recognition of deferred revenue for the delivery of product and feature commitments.
In reviewing our top 10 customers, 5 were telcos, 3 of which were outside of the U.S.; 4 were cloud and cable providers; and 1 was an enterprise customer. We expect this diversification trend to continue, demonstrating the increased relevance of our product portfolio across multiple verticals and geographies. 
Our underlying demand metrics were healthy this quarter, with a year-over-year and sequential increase in product deferred revenue and a product book-to-bill greater than one. For the quarter, we delivered strong year-over-year non-GAAP operating margin and earnings per share expansion, which reflects our solid execution, focus on revenue growth, effective management of our cost structure and significant reduction in share count. We are pleased that we delivered results in line with our long-term model of 39% non-GAAP operating expense as a percentage of revenue.
In the quarter, we had strong cash flow from operations of $293 million as a direct result of our improved operating margin. CapEx for the quarter also increased to $71 million as we focus on investments to drive long-term productivity and support continued innovation and development of new products. 
We repurchased $15 million of shares and paid $39 million of dividends. Since Q1 of 2014, inclusive of share repurchases and dividends, we returned approximately $3.5 billion of capital to shareholders against our commitment to return $4.1 billion by the end of 2016.
Now let's take a look at some of the underlying assumptions behind our outlook for Q4. We expect the demand environment across multiple verticals to remain healthy and anticipate the diversification of our revenue to continue. We expect continued uncertainty around the macro environment in China and certain parts of Europe, which we have factored into our outlook. We also anticipate the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar to other currencies to remain strong. 
I'm very pleased with the ongoing operational discipline, including operating expense management across the company. Our new products are gaining traction with our customers. Given the underlying healthy demand environment and to ensure that we capture the growth opportunity from these new products, we anticipate making modest increases to our go-to-market resources over the next few quarters while remaining in line with our long-term model of non-GAAP operating expense as a percentage of revenue of 39%. You can find the detailed outlook to Q4 in the CFO commentary available on our website. 
To summarize, I am pleased with the strong performance in Q3, including demonstrating the ability to achieve our long-term model. We anticipate overall demand to remain healthy across our target verticals articles and geographies.
We continue to see good traction with our customers for our new product innovation as evidenced by new design wins and a growing pipeline. As we close out the year, we remain focused on execution and delivering on our strategic commitment. I would like to thank our team for their continued dedication and commitment to Juniper's success. 
And now I'd like to open the call for questions.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Jim Suva of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Jim Suva of Citi.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick question. You mentioned about investing more for the future but still within your financial goals, which is great. For the investing in those items, can you help us a little bit more? Is that focused on, say, geographic expansion or product expans
componenttext: A quick question. You mentioned about investing more for the future but still within your financial goals, which is great. For the investing in those items, can you help us a little bit more? Is that focused on, say, geographic expansion or product expansion or certain areas of, like, software security or certain parts that you're a little bit softer in? And also the timing of when these harvesting of these investments should start to see some growth, where we should start to see some fruit from that investment.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question and the comments, Jim. Let me just start, and then I'll pass it over to Robyn. First and foremost, as a pure-play innovator, the goal for Juniper is really to continue to make sure that we have really differentiated products i
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question and the comments, Jim. Let me just start, and then I'll pass it over to Robyn. First and foremost, as a pure-play innovator, the goal for Juniper is really to continue to make sure that we have really differentiated products in the market segments that we are going after. We have incredible product pipeline, as we've talked about earlier this year, and it's now in the process of shipping. And we've also consistently said that when we invest, we're going to invest in a way in a prudent manner with discipline that's commensurate with our growth as a company. That's a discipline that Robyn and I are absolutely driving through the organization right now, and it's one that I think is paying off if you just take a look at the profitability metrics in terms of operating margin and OpEx as a percentage of total revenue for the company and the Q3 time frame. And I'll pass it to Robyn. Do you want to add anything else?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So specifically, Jim, what I mentioned in my commentary was that we will invest modestly as we move forward here on the go-to-market side. As Rami mentioned, from a product delivery point of view, we're very excited by the new products that we are de
componenttext: Yes. So specifically, Jim, what I mentioned in my commentary was that we will invest modestly as we move forward here on the go-to-market side. As Rami mentioned, from a product delivery point of view, we're very excited by the new products that we are delivering into the market. We've seen good receptivity to those products. And so we're adding prudently to the go-to-market effort to make sure that we are capturing the opportunity that's out there.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Tal Liani of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question is from Tal Liani of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just first, to follow up to the previous question. Does it mean -- so you're now at an operating margin of about 25%, give or take. What does it mean from a margin target? The fact you want to invest more, what does it mean from a margin target going forw
componenttext: Just first, to follow up to the previous question. Does it mean -- so you're now at an operating margin of about 25%, give or take. What does it mean from a margin target? The fact you want to invest more, what does it mean from a margin target going forward? That's number one. Number two, I want ask more about the market itself. There was a routing cycle. You recovered from some weakness we had in previous quarters. How is -- what's the outlook? Is -- was there just a recovery from the lows and then there is a new level, and from there, it goes flat because I see it was flat sequentially this quarter? Or do you see demand continuing to creep up, go up because of certain reasons? If you can identify the reasons.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Tal. So let me start, and then I'll also hand it over to Robyn. On the margin target, I think the results that you saw in Q3 with respect to our operating margins being north of 25% and also, again, our OpEx as a percentage of revenue being
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Tal. So let me start, and then I'll also hand it over to Robyn. On the margin target, I think the results that you saw in Q3 with respect to our operating margins being north of 25% and also, again, our OpEx as a percentage of revenue being in line with our long-term model, the long-term model that we outlined to our shareholders at the end of 2014 is intact. And the results that you see here, so this should essentially give you confidence as it gives us a lot of confidence that we can absolutely achieve that long-term model. That's how we -- that's how I would think about it. And certainly, that requires a level of disciplined execution and investment that we are driving through the company today that I'm, honestly, quite proud of how the team is executing on. On the second question with respect to routing, the trends that we're seeing in routing in the second half are largely playing out as we have been describing over the last several quarters. We've said that there should be some improvement in telco spending in the second half of the year, and that's essentially happening. We did see that improvement, not only in the Tier 1, but also in non-Tier 1 service providers. Bookings for routings was actually quite healthy in Q3. I think the softness was essentially as a result of cloud at difficult compare relative to Q2 because of the revenue recognition event we had in that quarter. But visibility is solid, and the product pipeline has never been this good in many, many years in the company. So I actually feel good about where we are with respect to routing. Robyn?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I think you said it well on the margin side. In terms of the percentage of revenue for OpEx, we are targeting 39%, as we've -- we outlined last year. And I will point out that whilst we got to the model this quarter, we did get there last quarter
componenttext: Yes, no, I think you said it well on the margin side. In terms of the percentage of revenue for OpEx, we are targeting 39%, as we've -- we outlined last year. And I will point out that whilst we got to the model this quarter, we did get there last quarter as well from an operating margin perspective. There's still a lot of work to be done to get there on a sustainable basis on an annualized basis.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Simona Jankowski of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Simona Jankowski of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rami, you commented on the recent industry consolidation, but then you also made a comment that the world needs a company like Juniper. I was just curious, was that a reference to a preference you have to remain stand-alone versus participating in the con
componenttext: Rami, you commented on the recent industry consolidation, but then you also made a comment that the world needs a company like Juniper. I was just curious, was that a reference to a preference you have to remain stand-alone versus participating in the consolidation? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for the question, Simona. You look at the industry right now, certainly, there are examples of consolidation. There's at least one example where the exact opposite of a split is in fact happening. But the things that I want everybody to be aw
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for the question, Simona. You look at the industry right now, certainly, there are examples of consolidation. There's at least one example where the exact opposite of a split is in fact happening. But the things that I want everybody to be aware of is the massive transformation that's just happening in terms of technology in terms of a new approach in -- that service providers and enterprises are using to deliver value to their end users. That requires things like virtualization, requires things like automation and visibility and analytics. And that, in my mind, requires that there be somebody that's absolutely focused on innovation in the space of IP networking. And I believe that's the role that we satisfy in this industry. As I go around the world and talk to our customers, CIOs, CTOs, CEOs, they all have a common theme in terms of the requirements, which is a technology provider that can partner with them to offer a new way for them to deliver service as a value to their end users. And they view us as that right partner, and that's I think the role that we satisfy.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up question, which is to do with your MX product which has been very successful over the years. Some of your competitors, Cisco, Arista and others, are talking about addressing some of the routing features and the routing stack in a
componenttext: And then just a follow-up question, which is to do with your MX product which has been very successful over the years. Some of your competitors, Cisco, Arista and others, are talking about addressing some of the routing features and the routing stack in an aggregated fashion on the switching platforms in the data center. And I think you guys are considering or working on doing something similar. But can you just address how that development might impinge on the opportunity for the MX and whether that's cannibalistic whether you do it to yourselves or others do it you.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks for the questions, Simona. So the MX success is a result of a few different things. But one of the biggest elements of its success has to do with the diversity of use cases that it satisfies. It really has turned into the standard Swiss Army
componenttext: Sure. Thanks for the questions, Simona. So the MX success is a result of a few different things. But one of the biggest elements of its success has to do with the diversity of use cases that it satisfies. It really has turned into the standard Swiss Army knife, if you will, for this industry, where it has the ability to deliver all sorts of services, whether they be business or residential, or to serve at the edge of the data center, connecting data centers together or connecting data centers to the consumers of cloud services. I think it's very difficult for anybody to target the MX in its entirety with all of the use cases that it serves. That flexibility is a flexibility that we've built ground up from the start to make it very competitive. Now that said, I'm not confused about the fact that this industry is a competitive industry, and we have to innovate in that way. Yes, I do believe that there will be competition that will go after specific use cases that the MX does target. And in that case, we either show and demonstrate the flexibility of the MX in solving that use case in a better way. Or we do have options ourselves with other products that we can use in our portfolio, whether it be the PTX or the new QFX10000, that can solve a particular use case in a more efficient manner. So I -- think about it from a standpoint of, yes, the industry is competitive. We now have a diverse tool chest between the MX, the PTX and the QFX that give us all of the weapons that we need to compete effectively.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rod Hall of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Rod Hall of JPMorgan.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to focus all a bit more on switching the numbers better than we expected. Momentum there continues, yet a lot of other data points out there are pointing to enterprise spending limits. So I just wonder, Robyn, could you just comment on where
componenttext: I just wanted to focus all a bit more on switching the numbers better than we expected. Momentum there continues, yet a lot of other data points out there are pointing to enterprise spending limits. So I just wonder, Robyn, could you just comment on where we are with the major projects that you guys are seeing and switching or implementing? And have you added more of those projects? Is that what's allowing you guys to buck the trend? And then I've got a follow-up.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rod. In switching, I think the strength was broad-based in that we saw a good diversity of business across both the service front or in the enterprise. We also saw healthy demand for switching around the world, which certainly helped. And when you t
componenttext: Sure, Rod. In switching, I think the strength was broad-based in that we saw a good diversity of business across both the service front or in the enterprise. We also saw healthy demand for switching around the world, which certainly helped. And when you think about switching, for us, it really comes down to cloud. There is a consistent theme across pretty much all of our market verticals. In the Enterprise, there is a cloud-first mentality, where CIOs are looking to move workloads and applications to the cloud. And the service provider segment and the cable provider segments, they are looking at delivering more value to end users through cloud-based architectures. I think our switching, routing and security portfolios are coming together under the MetaFabric architecture framework in a way that's really resonating with our customers. And the road map with the new set of spine switches that we're in the process of shifting into the market today is looking very solid in the eyes of our customers. I think I'm bullish on the long-term prospects for switching given all of these trends and because of the differentiation that we have in our product portfolio.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Pierre Ferragu of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question is from Pierre Ferragu of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would want to want ask many questions. You've been doing so great on so many dimensions, so maybe I'll just restrict it to switching and security. In switching, I'd be curious to know is -- how, like, the ramp-up of your new product, your high-density s
componenttext: I would want to want ask many questions. You've been doing so great on so many dimensions, so maybe I'll just restrict it to switching and security. In switching, I'd be curious to know is -- how, like, the ramp-up of your new product, your high-density spine, QFX switch is going and how much it has been impacting numbers this quarter. And if we should expect some upside from this product trend, perhaps, on a 1- or 2-quarter horizon? And then on securities, it's impressive to see the SRX platform doing so well at the moment. And I'd be curious to know where you're winning with the platform at the moment. And how are you replacing like an aging installed base that you had out there? So is that a product cycle? Are you winning in this? Are you displacing competitors? That would be very good know that. And then as almost everybody asked it, I can't help asking you one more question on cost then and how we should think about that going forward. Would that be fair to think that you guys whatever think -- whichever we think happen going forward, are probably not going to grow your cost base and your OpEx faster than your revenues? Is that a fair statement? I'm sorry for the embarrassing question.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that's okay, Pierre. Let me handle the cost one first, and then Rami will talk about switching and security. So on the cost side, absolutely, we are focused on the discipline around cost management that we've shown over the last few years. And we are
componenttext: No, that's okay, Pierre. Let me handle the cost one first, and then Rami will talk about switching and security. So on the cost side, absolutely, we are focused on the discipline around cost management that we've shown over the last few years. And we are very focused on making sure that we only add modest amount of cost. The increase between Q3 and Q4, I gave you the midpoint of $500 million plus or minus in terms of the OpEx. The majority of that increase quarter-over-quarter -- or the vast majority is actually variable comp. So what we're talking about is modest increases in our go-to-market. We're very focused on delivering the leverage in the model that we believe is there in line with our long-term model.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Pierre, let me touch on switching and security. So we've -- in the spine switches, we've now shipped the first version of the family of new QFX10000 spine switches. We anticipate that we'll get the second version now into our customers' hands before t
componenttext: And Pierre, let me touch on switching and security. So we've -- in the spine switches, we've now shipped the first version of the family of new QFX10000 spine switches. We anticipate that we'll get the second version now into our customers' hands before the end of the year. The traction that we're seeing is solid. I think these products have been now in our customers' labs for some time, and we're getting feedback. And we are essentially putting the finishing touches on those products. I will say that the team really pushed the limits of technology in developing these products, and we did it with the hope and the anticipation that we will have some true differentiation. And it's playing out exactly as we have predicted in terms of our differentiation relative to what's out in the market. I feel very good about that. All that being said, we have consistently said that modest revenue in the second half of this year. And that's how I would think about it, with the growth really starting to happen next year. On the security side, if you recall, earlier in the year, we talked about our security pivot. We talked about reaping synergies from the standpoint of technology and cost as well as revenue. We talked about switch -- security as being intimately tied to the network, and the initial focus for us was on the high end. If we offer a cloud network or a campus network to our customers, we want them to have the peace of mind that it will be resilient, it'll be high-quality, it'll be resilient to attacks from the bad guys. And that means that you should be able to secure the network without slowing it down. So with the initial focus on the high end, I think we've increased the confidence in the eyes of our customer. We've improved the performance of the product line dramatically. Now in fact, the high-end SRX is the fastest firewall in the industry. And so for certain use cases, around the edge of the cloud or in service provider mobile infrastructure, we really have a differentiated product, and we're starting to see the effects of that. That said, I don't -- I am not yet calling mission accomplished on security. We've said that 2015 will be the year of stability. And there's still a lot of work, quite frankly, for us to do to shore up the rest of the product portfolio, especially as it comes to the Enterprise. And that's exactly what we're focused on right now. So pleased with what we've done thus far. A lot more work for us to do.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just to punctuate that, as we've said numerous times, this year is a year of stabilizing the security business. Year-to-date, we are flat with 2014. Obviously, we hope to grow that business next year. But we're pleased with the progress to date.
componenttext: Yes. And just to punctuate that, as we've said numerous times, this year is a year of stabilizing the security business. Year-to-date, we are flat with 2014. Obviously, we hope to grow that business next year. But we're pleased with the progress to date. And I just wanted to pull the background with your specific question, Pierre. We will grow revenues faster than OpEx as we move forward. That was part of our guidance when we set the long-term model last year. So I just wanted to clarify that.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: With that, we will turn to Rod Hall for his follow-up question.
componenttext: With that, we will turn to Rod Hall for his follow-up question.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I was just going to ask about the routing business. I wonder if you guys could comment on what you think happened to your share this quarter, your market share. And also on the Contrail win on AT&T, which -- by the way, congratulations on that. Just wo
componenttext: So I was just going to ask about the routing business. I wonder if you guys could comment on what you think happened to your share this quarter, your market share. And also on the Contrail win on AT&T, which -- by the way, congratulations on that. Just wondering if you could maybe give us a little idea what the revenue opportunity there might look like, what sorts of products that might pull through.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rod. On market share, I don't think all of the reports are out quite yet. But I -- these share reports, you have to look at them and dissect them into different areas. I think in the Edge, based on the wins and the project that we've been executing
componenttext: Sure, Rod. On market share, I don't think all of the reports are out quite yet. But I -- these share reports, you have to look at them and dissect them into different areas. I think in the Edge, based on the wins and the project that we've been executing on, there is a large dynamic that's happening around the world, especially here in the U.S. and in EMEA for Edge modernization, consolidation, simplification of Edge architecture. And just based on the project activity, I believe that we're doing quite well there. In the core, I think it's going to take a little bit of time for us as we go through the transition from T Series to the next generation to the PTX that we are shipping this year that we've launched in the early part of this year. So I'm not sure what's going to happen there with respect to share. But I feel good about the roadmap and the focus in terms of the prospects for share gains going forward into next year. On Contrail, yes, I mean, you pointed out one of the wins that we are very proud of, and that is with AT&T. But let me say that pretty much every strategic discussion that we're having with our customers around the world, especially on the service provider side but also on some larger enterprises that are looking at transforming the way in which they manage their networks to simplify the operations of those networks and to add far greater agility in how they deliver services over those networks, they are thinking about approach and Contrail is part of that discussion. So we added 4 new paying customers. I think the engagements have expanded, the developer community for the open source Contrail project is only growing the amount of innovation that's not coming, not just from Juniper, but from our partners around the industry is also growing. I'm really proud of what the Contrail team has done and continues to do. And AT&T, I mean, certainly extremely proud of that project, but I think that's just an example of others that were also engaging in.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jess Lubert of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question is from Jess Lubert of Wells Fargo.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, I was hoping you could tell us of getting 10% customers in the period. And if so, what category they would fall into? And then secondly, in Europe, it looks like your carrier business was fairly strong. So just help me understand if that was driven
componenttext: First, I was hoping you could tell us of getting 10% customers in the period. And if so, what category they would fall into? And then secondly, in Europe, it looks like your carrier business was fairly strong. So just help me understand if that was driven by a handful of large deals that will tail off after a quarter or 2, or if that was driven by a larger number of transactions that might be more sustainable. And then perhaps you can provide an update on the Nokia partnership, how's that proceeding, how confident you are on your ability to navigate any disruption once that deal closes.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so just in terms of 10% customers, there were no 10% customers in the quarter. Again, part of the strength of this quarter was actually the diversification of revenue in the quarter, again, with Enterprise actually being quite strong, telco being qui
componenttext: Yes, so just in terms of 10% customers, there were no 10% customers in the quarter. Again, part of the strength of this quarter was actually the diversification of revenue in the quarter, again, with Enterprise actually being quite strong, telco being quite strong, and obviously a sequential decline that's still very healthy year-over-year growth in the cloud providers and cable area. So I'll let Rami talk through the EMEA service provider business.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in Europe, actually the strength was fairly broad-based. It was both on the service provider, the key or the Tier 1 telecom operators, but also in the Enterprise and particularly in government. So I actually am pretty pleased with the broad-based
componenttext: Sure. So in Europe, actually the strength was fairly broad-based. It was both on the service provider, the key or the Tier 1 telecom operators, but also in the Enterprise and particularly in government. So I actually am pretty pleased with the broad-based strength of the business. There are certainly large deals in the SP space. There are typically going to be large deals that drive the overall performance. But I don't think there's anything that's atypical, if you will, in that -- in the quarter. And then I will say that the projects that we're engaging in are really around a number of key use cases. Edge modernization, in particular, such as, for example, the announcement that we made recently with Telefonica Spain, seems to be a really key theme in that region. I think the operators are looking to streamline their networks and deliver more value with greater agility over these networks. And for that, you need a universal Edge-type product. And the MX satisfies that role quite naturally. On the Nokia, I think we're executing to our strategy and the plan that we outlined in the last earnings call. We have enjoyed a deep relationship with all of our customers around the world. And where there is a need to make a change in our go-to-market approach, we're doing that. And we're doing it to a schedule that, I think, is working very well for us. So no concern from that front.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian White of Drexel.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian White of Drexel.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could comment a little about this product cycle. I know we're ramping up this year, but if you had to provide us with an idea where we are in the revenue generation from this product cycle, that would be great in terms of what percentage w
componenttext: I wonder if you could comment a little about this product cycle. I know we're ramping up this year, but if you had to provide us with an idea where we are in the revenue generation from this product cycle, that would be great in terms of what percentage we are, the way through. And just the AT&T win, for the carrier software to find networking, maybe just a little more color on why Juniper was chosen. And does this cannibalize existing business? Or net-net, this is incremental for Juniper?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. On the product cycle, and I'm assuming here you're talking about the newer products that we're introducing in the market across routing, switching and security. It's still early stages. We've consistently said second half, we'll see modest
componenttext: Thanks, Brian. On the product cycle, and I'm assuming here you're talking about the newer products that we're introducing in the market across routing, switching and security. It's still early stages. We've consistently said second half, we'll see modest revenue on the routing side. We haven't yet shipped the enhancements to the PTX product line that we're very excited about. I think the growth where it will really start to happen in a meaningful way in 2016 and the early customer interest give us confidence that these products are hitting the mark in terms of the challenges that they solve for our customers. On AT&T, it's a couple of different projects that have been announced. One is that we are participating in AT&T's Network on Demand initiative. We're doing this. Essentially, we're offering or partnering with them to offer to end-user's enterprises a new way of deriving value from their network that gives far more flexibility into the hands of the customer itself. So they will have the ability to choose on demand the kind of services that they want AT&T to deliver to them. And it's a very software-centric approach to market that has traditionally been driven by hardware and complexity. And we want it, quite frankly, because we have challenged the way in which these solutions were delivered historically. We had actually little to nothing to lose, because this is essentially a net new market opportunity for Juniper. And so demonstrated to AT&T that we were very willing partners in that technology transformation, and we're delighted that we were successful. And the second project is really around the various strategic network control point, this being Contrail, that will provide the network automation in their next-generation central offices. And this is where I provided the commentary that is just an example of the types of engagements that we're having with service providers around the world. The fact is that FPs are really looking to a new approach to running their next-generation network facilities and delivering value from those facilities. And the network controllers is a very strategic control point in the new architecture, and Contrail and the traction we're seeing is something that's very encouraging to us.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Sanjiv Wadhwani of Stifel.
componenttext: The next question is from Sanjiv Wadhwani of Stifel.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rami, I had a question about growth. I mean, a year ago at the Analyst Day, you had talked about 3% to 6% 3-year growth rate and understanding that it might fluctuate in any given year. I'm wondering if you can comment if next year might be a typical year
componenttext: Rami, I had a question about growth. I mean, a year ago at the Analyst Day, you had talked about 3% to 6% 3-year growth rate and understanding that it might fluctuate in any given year. I'm wondering if you can comment if next year might be a typical year, fall within that range and how so many of your new products that really start ramping next year might help out in terms of growth rate next year.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Sanjiv. I mean, we are just going to stick to what we provided you at the end of 2014 in terms of a 3-year view. Certainly, the results that we're seeing this year give us the confidence that we can achieve that 3-year view in terms of growth
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Sanjiv. I mean, we are just going to stick to what we provided you at the end of 2014 in terms of a 3-year view. Certainly, the results that we're seeing this year give us the confidence that we can achieve that 3-year view in terms of growth. I think the fundamentals of the industry are solid. I think the spending environment is good. The product roadmap is healthy. And all of those factors come together to give me the confidence in our ability to actually achieve the growth target that we provided you.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We'll -- Sanjiv, we will provide you with some color into next year as we round out this year in terms of what we're expecting from a growth rate perspective.
componenttext: Yes. We'll -- Sanjiv, we will provide you with some color into next year as we round out this year in terms of what we're expecting from a growth rate perspective.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess just a quick follow up, when you look at the new products, do you think that could add to some dimension in growth, just given that they're starting to ramp next year? Just qualitatively, not just in terms of the actual addition or subtraction
componenttext: And I guess just a quick follow up, when you look at the new products, do you think that could add to some dimension in growth, just given that they're starting to ramp next year? Just qualitatively, not just in terms of the actual addition or subtraction in numbers.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes -- I mean, as we've been saying consistently, our new product revenues, so the products that we announced earlier this year, in March, will contribute very modestly to revenue in 2015. We expect the revenue growth for next year to be more substa
componenttext: Well, yes -- I mean, as we've been saying consistently, our new product revenues, so the products that we announced earlier this year, in March, will contribute very modestly to revenue in 2015. We expect the revenue growth for next year to be more substantial.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from James Faucette of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from James Faucette of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a similar question. But if we go back to last year, last fall, as you were kind of outlining your growth targets, one of the key tenants that you focused on was the eventual need for carriers to increase their spending, particularly o
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a similar question. But if we go back to last year, last fall, as you were kind of outlining your growth targets, one of the key tenants that you focused on was the eventual need for carriers to increase their spending, particularly on cores, as core capacity was exhausted. At the same time, as we fast forward to this year, service providers are spending, at least among the U.S., it's still been relatively flat without seeing much improvement there. I'm wondering if you could give a little bit of color what may be allowing the carriers in U.S. to do that. And secondly, as they do start to increase their spend, how much of an additional tailwind can this be? It seems like with the good growth we've seen with the U.S. Tier 1s kicking in perhaps like the -- an accelerator. And then similarly, on security, you're delivering good year-over-year growth in that line in spite of the fact that you're characterizing it as a stable -- 2015 as a stabilization year. So if that's the case, should we expect to see further acceleration in security in 2016 as you turn the corner and start to enter into what you think to be your true growth?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, James. So thanks for the question. There's a lot in there. I mean, I'll see if I can address it all. First, in terms of carrier spending, as I mentioned, things are largely playing out as we expected in the second half. And I expect the next quarter
componenttext: Okay, James. So thanks for the question. There's a lot in there. I mean, I'll see if I can address it all. First, in terms of carrier spending, as I mentioned, things are largely playing out as we expected in the second half. And I expect the next quarter, Q4, to alter this current quarter, to also be a good quarter for us in terms of carrier spending. The dynamics between core and Edge -- actually, I've been consistently saying that it's become very difficult to break out those 2 domains. Much of the pressure that's happening in telecom networks today is, in fact, happening in the metro, happening in the Edge. And a lot of the products that have traditionally been used or deployed in the core, now actually going in the Edge to deal with that traffic capacity. So I'm really more measuring our success in carrier routing from an overall routing standpoint as opposed to specific to one domain or the other. That said, despite the fact that we are seeing some improvement in Telcos, we're not counting on that alone in driving our overall revenue growth. We're counting on continued diversity in our business. We saw that play out in the last couple of quarters with cloud kicking in to help some weakness in carrier spending. We're seeing it now this quarter with diversity across the Enterprise, governments and different geos. All of that is kicking in to support the overall growth. And it's really been -- demonstrates the power of that strategy to diversify our business from a technology standpoint, from a market vertical standpoint and also from a geo standpoint. On security, again, this year is all about stability. As Robyn mentioned, essentially, we're flat year-to-date. We still have -- I feel very good upon where we -- the work that has been done thus far on shoring up our competitiveness in the service provider, high-end security space and in the cloud. We still have some more work to do on the Enterprise side. And just in Q3, we announced a series of enhancements to our security portfolio under the umbrella of a new architecture called Juniper Unite, that essentially brings to bear our security switching and routing assets together to create far more agility, simplicity and ease of management that's so important to our Enterprise customers in the campus and in the campus domain. And that's what we're working on right now. And I think that, that plays out and results in growth in 2015 time frame.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And let me just add to the first part of your question. So on telco, we actually saw good growth in the quarter, both sequentially and year-over-year on telco globally. Modestly in the U.S., that globally, it was a nice quarter for growth. So we are actua
componenttext: And let me just add to the first part of your question. So on telco, we actually saw good growth in the quarter, both sequentially and year-over-year on telco globally. Modestly in the U.S., that globally, it was a nice quarter for growth. So we are actually anticipating that diversification to continue and we are expecting that to continue to improve again, modestly.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: I guess it's for Rami. And a lot speaks on this call about diversifying your revenue base. Versus the charts that we saw last Analyst Meeting, can you update in terms of how diversified you are now? And if you can give some of those numbers, maybe can you help us with are you sufficiently diversified now? Do you feel comfortable whereby Juniper could see through cycle revenue growth that will continuously and be -- and you could offset on a continuous basis the typical service provider cycle that we see?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Kulbinder. So I know that, that data that we have provided has been very useful, and I think we can look to providing an updated view in the future. From just a qualitative standpoint, the strategy itself is definitely working out in terms of
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Kulbinder. So I know that, that data that we have provided has been very useful, and I think we can look to providing an updated view in the future. From just a qualitative standpoint, the strategy itself is definitely working out in terms of helping us offset what is, in fact, a cyclical industry. Do we believe that we can completely offset large cycles that might happen in Telcos? No, I think that's a pretty tall order. But that said, I think we've demonstrated with not just diversity from a market vertical standpoint, but diversity across technology areas, switching running security, and diversity across geos. I mean, you look at Q3, Enterprise kicked in, and also EMEA and APAC kicked in that helped us in, again, creating the overall growth. I think this strategy works. I think it has legs. And I think that they will help us in the future.

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe just one very quick slightly different question. Let me ask you about the question from consolidation came up from a Juniper perspective, it seems to me that you guys are hitting most of the targets or heading towards more of the target that you
componenttext: And maybe just one very quick slightly different question. Let me ask you about the question from consolidation came up from a Juniper perspective, it seems to me that you guys are hitting most of the targets or heading towards more of the target that you won. The one that I've always been uncertain about is what's your own approach to M&A like, given that you are achieving your margin structure, generating good cash returning, cash growing? Is now the time for Juniper to be a bit more active on the M&A front, do you think? I mean, you can maybe accelerate, I mean, your growth? Or is that not how you see the business?

headline: Juniper Networks, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm actually open to M&A. And it will be, as I have mentioned historically, very much complementary to our strategy, tuck-in type technology M&A, that will be easy to integrate and work to accelerate the strategy that we're already executing on. Havi
componenttext: Yes, I'm actually open to M&A. And it will be, as I have mentioned historically, very much complementary to our strategy, tuck-in type technology M&A, that will be easy to integrate and work to accelerate the strategy that we're already executing on. Having said that, we are so focused right now on putting the finishing touches on what is a huge product pipeline that's all coming to bear into the market simultaneously around the same time frame. I honestly do not want to distract the team too much from that right now. So timing is going to be important. But that said, I do believe that M&A can be a good part of our strategy with the right timing and certainly something that's complimentary to our overall strategy.
